Two of the new engines have yellow/orange exhaust plumes, and one has purple plumes (like the RAPIER), though I could be mistaken about the purple dominating as much as I'm imagining. I'll draw your attention to the exhaust plumes in the current pre-NASA crop of liquid fuel thrusters, which are all very consistently dominantly white with a subtle blue/purple tint at the edges. I'm in no way saying SRB and liquid thruster exhaust should look the same.

Now that I look at it, there's nothing wrong with the RAPIER exhaust plume other than the blue and purple appear to be reversed, making the purple appear more overwhelming.

Don't underestimate the asteroids.... an asteroid the size of a plane could destroy a whole LOT OF CRAP (In real life) since the kinetic velocity is very high... But If you slowed It down enough you could make the tidal wave or explosion be smaller

More arcade than reality. If an asteroid has a force great enough to cause a tidal wave (ie thousands of nuclear warheads) 'slowing it down' to lessen the wave would require a similar level of energy. Nobody at NASA is talking about depleting an asteroid's energy. It's about redirecting. A few 10ths of a m/s left or right to miss the earth, not a few thousand m/s in total velocity to lessen an impact.

Note also that NASA mostly talks about putting an asteroid in orbit around the moon, not earth. This is to lessen the delta-V changes necessary to establish an orbit, and to avoid any risk of de-orbiting onto new york.
